moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bb5 Bc: Rather than permit the "fork trick" 6...Nxe5 7.d4, Black sacrifices a pawn for rapid development.
moves.7. Nxc6 dxc6 8. Bc4 b5 9. Be2: The seemingly more logical 9.Bb3 fails to 9...Bg4 10.Qe1 [or 10.Ne2 Rxe4 winning the pinned Knight] 10...b4, and if 11.Na4 Rxe4 traps the White Queen.
If White were able to follow up with 13.d4, this would be a good move, but he can't. He should reconcile himself to 12.d3.
moves.12... Qd3 13. b4 Bb6 14. a4 bxa4 15. Qxa: Threatens mate with 17...Qxf1+. White's reply defends against this sacrifice but allows another, which Paulsen can hardly be blamed for missing. Relatively best was 17.Qd1
moves.17. Qa6 Qxf3 18. gxf3: Morphy took 12 minutes to decide on 17...Qxf3, an unusually long time for him. Paulsen, a notoriously slow player, thought for over an hour before capturing the queen.
moves.18... Rg6+ 19. Kh1 Bh3 20. Rd1: Black threatened 20...Bg2+ 21.Kg1 Bxf3++, and 20.Rg1 fails to 20...Rxg1+ 21.Kxg1 Re1+. The key line, which Paulsen probably missed at move 17, is 20.Qd3 [hoping to return the queen with 20...Qxg6] 20...f5! and White is helpless.
